comment.shortText:
The `binary_tree` Source Module provides functions for the interaction with binary trees, as covered the textbook
[Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs, JavaScript Adaptation (SICP JS)](https://sicp.comp.nus.edu.sg/)
in [section 2.3.3 Example: Representing Sets](https://sicp.comp.nus.edu.sg/chapters/37).
Click on a name on the left to see how they are defined and used.
Returns an empty binary tree, represented by the empty list null
Returns a binary tree node composed of the specified left subtree, value and right subtree.

tags.text:
```typescript
const tree = make_tree(1, make_empty_tree(), make_empty_tree());
display(tree); // Shows "[null, 1, null]" in the REPL
```

comment.text: Value to be stored in the node

comment.shortText:
The curves library provides functions for drawing "curves", i.e a sequence of
points that may/may not be connected by lines.
comment.text:
A point is defined by its coordinates (x, y and z), and the color assigned to
it (r, g, and b). A few constructors for points is given, together with the
corresponding selectors for querying the coordinates and color components
mentioned above.

Naturally, the central element of the library is the definition of Curve, a
unary function which takes a Number argument within the unit interval `[0,1]`
and returns a point. If `C` is a Curve, then the starting point of the curve
is always `C(0)`, and the ending point is always `C(1)`.

A Curve transformation is a function that takes a Curve as argument and
returns a Curve. Examples of Curve transformations are `scale` and `translate`.

Finally, a Curve drawer is function that takes a Number argument and returns
a function that takes in a Curve and visualises it in the output screen is
shown in the Source Academy in the tab with the "Curves Canvas" icon (image).
Examples of drawer functions are `draw_points_on` and `draw_connected`.

comment.shortText:
This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The points
lie on the right half of the unit circle. They start at Point (0,1) when t is
0. When t is 0.5, they reach Point (1,0), when t is 1, they reach Point
(0, -1).
comment.returns: Point in the arc at t

comment.shortText: Retrieves the blue component of a given Point.

This function is a binary Curve operator: It takes two Curves as arguments
and returns a new Curve. The two Curves are combined by using the full first
Curve for the first portion of the result and by using the full second Curve
for the second portion of the result. The second Curve is translated such
that its point at fraction 0 is the same as the Point of the first Curve at
fraction 1.

This function is a binary Curve operator: It takes two Curves as arguments
and returns a new Curve. The two Curves are combined by using the full first
Curve for the first portion of the result and by using the full second Curve
for the second portion of the result. The second Curve is not changed, and
therefore there might be a big jump in the middle of the result Curve.

Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. When a program evaluates to a Drawing, the Source system displays it
graphically, in a window, instead of textually. The parts between (0,0,0) and
(1,1,1) of the resulting Drawing are shown within the unit cube.

comment.text:
determines the number of points, lower than 65535, to be sampled.
Including 0 and 1, there are `num + 1` evenly spaced sample points

comment.shortText:
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. When a program evaluates to a Drawing, the Source system displays it
graphically, in a window, instead of textually. The Drawing is stretched or
shrunk to show the full curve and maximize its width and height within the
cube.

comment.text:
determines the number of points, lower than 65535, to be sampled.
Including 0 and 1, there are `num + 1` evenly spaced sample points

comment.shortText:
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. When a program evaluates to a Drawing, the Source system displays it
graphically, in a window, instead of textually. The Drawing is scaled
proportionally with its size maximized to fit entirely inside the cube.

comment.text:
determines the number of points, lower than 65535, to be sampled.
Including 0 and 1, there are `num + 1` evenly spaced sample points

comment.shortText:
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of
isolated points, and does not connect them. When a program evaluates to a
Drawing, the Source system displays it graphically, in a window, instead of
textually. The Drawing is scaled proportionally with its size maximized to
fit entirely inside the cube.

comment.shortText: Retrieves the green component of a given Point.

This function is a Curve transformation: a function from a Curve to a Curve.
The points of the result Curve are the same points as the points of the
original Curve, but in reverse: The result Curve applied to 0 is the original
Curve applied to 1 and vice versa.

Makes a 3D color Point with given x, y and z coordinates, and RGB values
ranging from 0 to 255. Any input lower than 0 for RGB will be rounded up to
0, and any input higher than 255 will be rounded down to 255.
comment.returns: with x, y and z as coordinates, and r, g and b as RGB values

comment.shortText: Makes a 3D Point with given x, y and z coordinates.
comment.returns: with x, y and z as coordinates

comment.shortText:
Makes a color Point with given x and y coordinates, and RGB values ranging
from 0 to 255. Any input lower than 0 for RGB will be rounded up to 0, and
any input higher than 255 will be rounded down to 255.
comment.returns: with x and y as coordinates, and r, g and b as RGB values

comment.shortText: Makes a Point with given x and y coordinates.
comment.returns: with x and y as coordinates

comment.shortText:
This function is a Curve transformation: It takes a Curve as argument and
returns a new Curve, as follows. A Curve is in standard position if it
starts at (0,0) ends at (1,0). This function puts the given Curve in
standard position by rigidly translating it so its start Point is at the
origin (0,0), then rotating it about the origin to put its endpoint on the
x axis, then scaling it to put the endpoint at (1,0). Behavior is unspecified
on closed Curves where start-point equal end-point.
Retrieves the red component of a given Point.

This function takes either 1 or 3 angles, a, b and c in radians as parameter
and returns a Curve transformation: a function that takes a Curve as argument
and returns a new Curve, which is the original Curve rotated by the given
angle around the z-axis (1 parameter) in counter-clockwise direction, or the
original Curve rotated extrinsically with Euler angles (a, b, c) about x, y,
and z axes (3 parameters).
comment.returns: function that takes a Curve and returns a Curve

comment.shortText:
This function takes scaling factors `a`, `b` and
`c`, each with default value of 1, as arguments and returns a
Curve transformation that scales a given Curve by `a` in
x-direction, `b` in y-direction and `c` in z-direction.
comment.returns: function that takes a Curve and returns a Curve

comment.shortText:
This function takes a scaling factor s argument and returns a Curve
transformation that scales a given Curve by s in x, y and z direction.
comment.returns: function that takes a Curve and returns a Curve

comment.shortText:
This function returns a Curve transformation: It takes an x-value x0, a
y-value y0 and a z-value z0, each with default value of 0, as arguments and
returns a Curve transformation that takes a Curve as argument and returns a
new Curve, by translating the original by x0 in x-direction, y0 in
y-direction and z0 in z-direction.

This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The points
lie on the unit circle. They start at Point (1,0) when t is 0. When t is
0.25, they reach Point (0,1), when t is 0.5, they reach Point (-1, 0), etc.
comment.returns: Point on the circle at t

comment.shortText:
This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The
x-coordinate at franction t is t, and the y-coordinate is 0.
comment.returns: Point on the line at t

comment.shortText:
This function is a Curve generator: it takes a number and returns a
horizontal curve. The number is a y-coordinate, and the Curve generates only
points with the given y-coordinate.
Retrieves the x-coordinate of a given Point.
Retrieves the y-coordinate of a given Point.
Retrieves the z-coordinate of a given Point.

The pix_n_flix library allows us to process still images and video. Each Image is a
two-dimensional array of Pixels, and a Pixel consists of red, blue and green color
values, each ranging from 0 and 255. To access these color values of a Pixel, we
provide the functions red_of, blue_of and green_of.
comment.text:
A central element of pix_n_flix is the notion of a Filter, a function that is applied
to two images: the source Image and the destination Image. We can install a given
Filter to be used to transform the Images that the camera captures into images
displayed on the output screen by using the function install_filter. The output
screen is shown in the Source Academy in the tab with the "Video Display" icon (camera).

The size of the output screen can be changed by the user. To access the current size of the
output screen, we provide the functions video_height and video_width.

comment.shortText: Returns the alpha component of a given Pixel.
comment.returns: The alpha component as a number between 0 and 255

comment.shortText: Returns the blue component of a given Pixel.
comment.returns: The blue component as a number between 0 and 255

comment.shortText:
Returns a new filter that is the result of applying both
filter1 and filter2 together.
comment.returns: Filter after applying filter1 and filter2

comment.shortText:
The default filter that just copies the input 2D
grid to output.
Returns the green component of a given Pixel.
comment.returns: The green component as a number between 0 and 255

comment.shortText:
Installs a given filter to be used to transform
the images that the camera captures into images
displayed on the screen.
comment.text:
A filter is a function that is applied to two
two-dimensional arrays of Pixels:
the source image and the destination image.

comment.shortText: Returns the red component of a given Pixel.
comment.returns: The red component as a number between 0 and 255

comment.shortText: Resets any filter applied on the video.

Sets height of video frame.
Note: Only accepts height and width within the range of 1 and 500.

Sets frames per second (FPS) of the video.
Note: Only accepts FPS values within the range of 2 to 30.

Assigns the red, green, blue and alpha components of a pixel
to given values.

comment.text: The red component as a number between 0 and 255
The green component as a number between 0 and 255
The blue component as a number between 0 and 255
The alpha component as a number between 0 and 255

comment.shortText: Takes a snapshot of image after a set delay.

comment.text: Delay in ms before a snapshot is taken

comment.shortText: Initialize the PixNFlix live feed with default globals.

Returns the current height of the output video display in
pixels, i.e. the number of pixels in vertical direction.

Returns the current width of the output video display in
pixels, i.e. the number of pixels in horizontal direction.
This is the official documentation for the repeat module.

Returns a new function which when applied to an argument, has the same effect
as applying the specified function to the same argument n times.
comment.returns: the new function that has the same effect as func repeated n times

tags.text:
```typescript
const plusFour = repeat(x => x + 2);
plusFour(0); // Returns 4
```

comment.text: the number of times to repeat the function

comment.shortText:
Returns a new function which when applied to an argument, has the same effect
as applying the specified function to the same argument 3 times.
comment.returns: the new function that has the same effect as `(x => func(func(func(x))))`

tags.text:
```typescript
const plusNine = thrice(x => x + 3);
plusNine(0); // Returns 9
```

comment.shortText:
Returns a new function which when applied to an argument, has the same effect
as applying the specified function to the same argument 2 times.
comment.returns: the new function that has the same effect as `(x => func(func(x)))`

tags.text:
```typescript
const plusTwo = twice(x => x + 1);
plusTwo(2); // Returns 4
```

comment.shortText: The sounds library provides functions for constructing and playing sounds.
comment.text:
A wave is a function that takes in a number `t` and returns
a number representing the amplitude at time `t`.
The amplitude should fall within the range of [-1, 1].

A Sound is a pair(wave, duration) where duration is the length of the sound in seconds.
The constructor make_sound and accessors get_wave and get_duration are provided.

Sound Discipline:
For all sounds, the wave function applied to and time `t` beyond its duration returns 0, that is:
`(get_wave(sound))(get_duration(sound) + x) === 0` for any x >= 0.

Two functions which combine Sounds, `consecutively` and `simultaneously` are given.
Additionally, we provide sound transformation functions `adsr` and `phase_mod`
which take in a Sound and return a Sound.

Finally, the provided `play` function takes in a Sound and plays it using your
computer's sound system.

comment.shortText:
Returns an envelope: a function from Sound to Sound.
When the adsr envelope is applied to a Sound, it returns
a new Sound with its amplitude modified according to parameters
The relative amplitude increases from 0 to 1 linearly over the
attack proportion, then decreases from 1 to sustain level over the
decay proportion, and remains at that level until the release
proportion when it decays back to 0.
comment.returns: Envelope a function from Sound to Sound

comment.text: proportion of Sound in attack phase
proportion of Sound in release phase

comment.shortText:
returns a Sound reminiscent of a bell, playing
a given note for a given duration
comment.returns: Sound resulting bell Sound with given pitch and duration

comment.shortText:
returns a Sound reminiscent of a cello, playing
a given note for a given duration
comment.returns: Sound resulting cello Sound with given pitch and duration

comment.shortText:
Makes a new Sound by combining the sounds in a given list
where the second sound is appended to the end of the first sound,
the third sound is appended to the end of the second sound, and
so on. The effect is that the sounds in the list are joined end-to-end
Accesses the duration of a given Sound.
Accesses the wave function of a given Sound.
comment.returns: the wave function of the Sound

tags.text: get_wave(make_sound(t => Math_sin(2 * Math_PI * 440 * t), 5)); // Returns t => Math_sin(2 * Math_PI * 440 * t)

comment.shortText:
Initialize recording by obtaining permission
to use the default device microphone
Checks if the argument is a Sound
comment.returns: true if x is a Sound, false otherwise

comment.shortText: Converts a letter name to its corresponding frequency.

Converts a letter name to its corresponding MIDI note.
The letter name is represented in standard pitch notation.
Examples are "A5", "Db3", "C#7".
Refer to <a href="https://i.imgur.com/qGQgmYr.png">this mapping from
letter name to midi notes.

Makes a Sound with given wave function and duration.
The wave function is a function: number -> number
that takes in a non-negative input time and returns an amplitude
between -1 and 1.
comment.returns: with wave as wave function and duration as duration

tags.text: const s = make_sound(t => Math_sin(2 * Math_PI * 440 * t), 5);

comment.shortText: Converts a MIDI note to its corresponding frequency.
comment.returns: the frequency of the MIDI note

comment.shortText: Makes a noise sound with given duration

comment.text: the duration of the noise sound

comment.shortText:
Returns a SoundTransformer which uses its argument
to modulate the phase of a (carrier) sine wave
of given frequency and duration with a given Sound.
Modulating with a low frequency Sound results in a vibrato effect.
Modulating with a Sound with frequencies comparable to
the sine wave frequency results in more complex wave forms.
comment.returns: function which takes in a Sound and returns a Sound

comment.text: the frequency of the sine wave to be modulated
the duration of the output soud
the amount of modulation to apply to the carrier sine wave

comment.shortText:
returns a Sound reminiscent of a piano, playing
a given note for a given duration
comment.returns: Sound resulting piano Sound with given pitch and duration

comment.shortText:
Plays the given Sound using the computer’s sound device.
The sound is only played if no other sounds are currently being played.

Plays the given Sound using the computer’s sound device
on top of any sounds that are currently playing.

comment.returns: promise: nullary function which returns the recorded sound

comment.shortText: Makes a sawtooth wave sound with given frequency and duration

comment.text: the frequency of the sawtooth wave sound
the duration of the sawtooth wave sound

comment.shortText: Makes a silence sound with given duration

comment.text: the duration of the silence sound

comment.shortText:
Makes a new Sound by combining the sounds in a given list
where all the sounds are overlapped on top of each other.
Makes a sine wave sound with given frequency and duration

comment.text: the frequency of the sine wave sound
the duration of the sine wave sound

comment.shortText: Makes a square wave sound with given frequency and duration

comment.text: the duration of the square wave sound

comment.shortText:
Returns a Sound that results from applying a list of envelopes
to a given wave form. The wave form is a Sound generator that
takes a frequency and a duration as arguments and produces a
Sound with the given frequency and duration. Each envelope is
applied to a harmonic: the first harmonic has the given frequency,
the second has twice the frequency, the third three times the
frequency etc. The harmonics are then layered simultaneously to
produce the resulting Sound.

comment.text: function from pair(frequency, duration) to Sound
duration of the produced Sound, in seconds
– list of envelopes, which are functions from Sound to Sound

comment.shortText: Stops all currently playing sounds.
Makes a triangle wave sound with given frequency and duration

comment.text: the frequency of the triangle wave sound
the duration of the triangle wave sound

returns a Sound reminiscent of a trombone, playing

comment.returns: Sound resulting trombone Sound with given pitch and duration

comment.shortText:
returns a Sound reminiscent of a violin, playing
a given note for a given duration
comment.returns: Sound resulting violin Sound with given pitch and duration

comment.shortText:
The stereo sounds library build on the sounds library by accommodating stereo sounds.
Within this library, all sounds are represented in stereo, with two waves, left and right.
comment.text:
A Stereo Sound is a `pair(pair(left_wave, right_wave), duration)` where duration is the length of the sound in seconds.
The constructor `make_stereo_sound` and accessors `get_left_wave`, `get_right_wave`, and `get_duration` are provided.
The `make_sound` constructor from sounds is syntatic sugar for `make_stereo_sounds` with equal waves.

comment.shortText:
Returns an envelope: a function from Sound to Sound.
When the adsr envelope is applied to a Sound, it returns
a new Sound with its amplitude modified according to parameters
The relative amplitude increases from 0 to 1 linearly over the
attack proportion, then decreases from 1 to sustain level over the
decay proportion, and remains at that level until the release
proportion when it decays back to 0.
comment.returns: Envelope a function from Sound to Sound

comment.shortText:
Returns a Sound Transformer that pans a sound based on the pan amount.
The input sound is first squashed to mono.
An amount of `-1` is a hard left pan, `0` is balanced, `1` is hard right pan.
comment.returns: a Sound Transformer that pans a Sound

comment.shortText:
Returns a Sound Transformer that uses a Sound to pan another Sound.
The modulator is treated as a mono sound and its output is used to pan
an input Sound.
`-1` is a hard left pan, `0` is balanced, `1` is hard right pan.
comment.returns: a Sound Transformer that pans a Sound

comment.text: the Sound used to modulate the pan of another sound
